_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.  Accidental Release Prevention



In this water treatment facility, we handle chlorine which is considered hazardous by the EPA.  The same property that makes this chemical valuable as a commodity also make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling to prevent unnecessary exposure, to reduce the threat to our own health and that of our co-workers, and to reduce the threat to nearby members of the community.  It is our policy to adhere to all Federal and State rules and regulations.  Safety depends upon the manner of which the chemicals are handled, the safety devices inherent in the design of this facility, the safe handing procedures that we use, and the training of our personnel.



2.  The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled



The purpose of this facility is to provide treatment of water for Hardin County Water District No. 2.  The regulated substance is stored on site is chlorine.  Chlorine is used in the treatment process to produce water that meets Federal and State standards.  The maximum inventory of chlorine is 4,000 pounds.  Chemical venders supply the chlorine to the facility by truck in one (1) ton containers.



3.  The Worst Case and Alternate release scenarios, include mitigation measures to limit the distances for chlorine scenarios.



Worst Case Scenario



Failure of one (1) ton chlorine cylinder would release 2,000 pounds of chemical.  It is assumed that the entire contents are released as gas, which is heavier than air.  The distance to endpoint of 0.0087 mg/L was determined by EPA's RMP Comp* Ver 1.07 to be 2.2 miles.  Public receptors within the distance are schools, hospitals, recreational areas, and community stores. The estimated population within the 2.2 mile radius using landview 6 information is 19,180.



4.  Alternate Release Scenario



A bad connection on one  (1) ton cylinder results in the release of gas through an opening equal to a 3/8" line.  This occurs indoors and is reduced 55% from 18.2

lbs/min to 10 lbs/min.  In our scenario, the chlorine detector fails to provide an alarm output to the halogen gas shutoff system.  Thirty (30) minutes pass before the Halogen system switch is activated.  Three hundred pounds of chlorine is released.  The distance to the endpoint of 0.0087 mg/l was determined by the EPA's RMP*CompVer 1.07 to be 0.1 miles.  The estimated residential population with the 0.1 mile radius is 0. 



This facility has developed a program with policies that meet the requirements of the EPA's Risk Management and OSHA Process Safety Management programs.



5.  Five Year Accident History



This facility has not experienced any chemical release of chlorine that resulted in deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



The Emergency Response Plan



Since facility personnel will only respond to incidential releases, we are required to develop an Emergency Action Plan to ensure employee safety rather than a full emergency response plan.  The Elizabethtown Fire Department will respond to and mitigate any threat by an accidental release of chlorine from our facility.   The facility is included in the Hardin County Emergency Planning Committee Response Plan.
